title: What did holiday shopping reveal about the US economy?
summary:
What did holiday shopping reveal about the US economy?
In 2025, shoppers opened their wallets with gusto, though consumers appeared to favor low-cost options and discounts, according to spending data shared with ABC News.
The performance defied concerns overhanging the economy for months, as hiring slowed and inflation ticked higher.
Seemingly undeterred, shoppers flexed their strength at the close of this year, offering some reassurance for the wider economy.
As of October, roughly half of buyers planned to use a by-now-pay-later plan for holiday shopping as a means of managing their budget, PayPal said.

title: Saving for a down payment is getting easier. Here are 8 markets where it takes under 5 years.
summary:
The time it takes to save for a home down payment fell to about seven years in 2025.
The time it takes to save for a home down payment fell to about seven years in 2025.
TrongNguyen/Getty ImagesThe time it takes to save for a home down payment fell to about seven years in 2025.
The good news for homebuyers is that the time it takes to save for a down payment has decreased in recent years.
Luckily, there are still affordable markets where it takes less than seven years to save for a down payment.

title: 7 things you may not know about dividends
summary:
Here are some of the most common questions I got:What should I know about reinvested dividends and wash sales?
If I reinvest dividends, will I end up with fractional shares that are difficult to sell?
Most major brokerages let you sell fractional shares, but you typically need to sell fractional shares as a market order, and liquidating fractional shares may take an additional day.
How are dividends taxed?
Dividends from holdings that don’t meet these requirements are nonqualified and are taxed as ordinary income.

title: Fed minutes show it could be 'some time' before another rate cut
summary:
00:00 BrookeThe Federal Reserve just released the minutes from its December meeting showing a tight split over the latest rate cut.
Cutting rates in December was a close call for some on the Federal Reserve, while some think it will be some time before they cut rates again, according to minutes from the December policy meeting that were released this afternoon.
00:30 Jennifer SchonbergerThose minutes read quote, most participants judged that further downward adjustments to the target range for the Fed funds rate would likely be appropriate if inflation declined over time as expected.
And still, there were a few, some of which we know, including Kansas City Fed President Jeff Schmid who thought a rate cut was not justified because there wasn't significant deterioration in the job market.
Bottom line here, Brooke, these minutes signaling that the Fed is not likely to cut rates again anytime soon.

title: Calculated Risk: FOMC Minutes: Further Cuts "Likely" Appropriate if Inflation Declines as Expected
Hedge funds had a strong 2025, but 3 charts show lurking risks that have investors on edge
summary:
More than 90% of allocators told the bank their hedge fund portfolios met or exceeded expectations — the highest share on record, Goldman said.
Through November, hedge funds gained 10.8% in 2025, according to PivotalPath's composite index, putting the industry on pace to eclipse 2024.
Hedge fund assets hit the $5 million mark at the end of September, according to industry watcher Hedge Fund Research.
But as the book closes on 2025, risks are emerging that have investors on edge, even amid the strong run.
Hedge fund allocators "continue to voice concerns around strategy over-exposure to the US large cap equity space," the report says.

title: IRS Announces New IRA Contribution Limits—Would You Be Ready for Retirement Saving That Much Annually?
summary:
In 2026, you can contribute up to $7,500 to your IRA, according to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).
Let's assume you start saving for retirement at age 27 and you plan to retire at age 67.
While IRA contribution limits typically increase every year to keep pace with inflation, let's assume that you stick to the 2026 contribution limit of $7,500 per year.
We can analyze two different scenarios: What if you put all of your money in an S&P 500 index fund?
Therefore, if someone had $882,000 in an IRA, the 4% rule assumes they could withdraw just $35,280 the first year of retirement.

title: 28 Richest Americans in History: Elon Musk, John D. Rockefeller
summary:
Standard Oil founder John D. Rockefeller has long been considered the wealthiest man in America's history, but Elon Musk is now wealthier.
Standard Oil founder John D. Rockefeller has long been considered the wealthiest man in America's history, but Elon Musk is now wealthier.
General Photographic Agency/Getty Images / ALLISON ROBBERT/AFP via Getty ImagesStandard Oil founder John D. Rockefeller has long been considered the wealthiest man in America's history, but Elon Musk is now wealthier.
General Photographic Agency/Getty Images / ALLISON ROBBERT/AFP via Getty Imageslighning bolt icon An icon in the shape of a lightning bolt.
One of the richest Americans of all time is widely considered to be Standard Oil founder John D. Rockefeller, whose wealth, at its peak in 1937, was equal to 1.5% of the country's GDP.

summary: The universe does not have laws -- it has habits, and habits can be broken.

title: Family stuns community with plans for their $20 million ranch: 'I don't think the shock has worn off'
summary:
Dale and Janet Veseth have decided to donate their $21.6 million ranch to the Ranchers Stewardship Alliance.
It wants to help ranchers use land wisely and participate in conservation so that ranching can remain sustainable for future generations.
Conni French, the RSA president, noted, "I think we were all completely taken aback, and honestly, I don't think the shock has worn off.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement AdvertisementThe Land Trust Alliance has noted that donations like these help on multiple fronts, including preserving habitats, addressing social inequality, and combating the climate crisis.
In Massachusetts, the White family signed over 400 acres of forest to the Land Conservation Trust.

title: SNAP Bans on Soda, Candy, and More Are Coming in Some States in 2026
summary:
New restrictions on what shoppers can buy with SNAP benefits are coming to some states in 2026.
New restrictions on what shoppers can buy with SNAP benefits are coming to some states in 2026.
Michael Loccisano/Getty ImagesNew restrictions on what shoppers can buy with SNAP benefits are coming to some states in 2026.
LouisianaLouisiana will restrict SNAP purchases of soft drinks, energy drinks, and candy starting February 18.
North DakotaNorth Dakota will restrict purchases of soft drinks, energy drinks, and candy for SNAP shoppers starting September 1.
